lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Exco Resources, Douglas Miller, raised his bid for shares of the company he does not already own by as much as 12 percent, to $217 million. Mr. Miller, who is leading a group of managers who want to take the company private, raised his offer to $18 a common share, a 3.4 percent premium over yesterday's closing price, and $18 to $18.25 for each preferred share, said the company, which explores for oil and natural gas. The transaction would also include the assumption of about $108 million in debt, the president, Ted Eubank, said. Mr. Miller owns about 10 percent of Exco's common stock, Mr. Eubank said. In August, Mr. Miller offered $17 for each common share and $17 to $18.05 for each preferred share, according to Exco.

abstract: China National Petroleum Corp withdraws bid to buy Russian government's 74.95 percent stake in oil company Slavneft after possible sale raises outcry among Russian politicians (S)
snippet: China National Petroleum Corp withdraws bid to buy Russian government's 74.95 percent stake in oil company Slavneft after possible sale raises outcry among Russian politicians (S)
lead_paragraph: China's main state oil producer withdrew its application to purchase a majority stake in one of Russia's largest oil companies after the possible sale raised an outcry among Russian politicians. Russian news media reported that the China National Petroleum Corporation would not bid on the Russian government's 74.95 percent stake in Slavneft, one of Russia's largest oil producers. The stake was expected to sell for at least $1.7 billion. Facing increasing shortfalls at home, China has been eager to increase its investments in oil production abroad. But Russian politicians expressed concern that Russia should not allow important state assets to fall into foreign hands.

abstract: Norwegian oil company Statoil agrees to sell its Navion shipping unit to Teekay Shipping Corp for about 6 billion kroner ($841 million); acquisition will more than double size of Teekay's tanker fleet (S)
snippet: Norwegian oil company Statoil agrees to sell its Navion shipping unit to Teekay Shipping Corp for about 6 billion kroner ($841 million); acquisition will more than double size of Teekay's tanker fleet (S)
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian oil company Statoil agreed to sell its Navion shipping unit to the Teekay Shipping Corporation for about 6 billion kroner ($841 million). The acquisition will more than double the size of Teekay's fleet, while Statoil will be able to focus on drilling. Navion's fleet includes 26 shuttle tankers that haul crude oil from North Sea oil fields, where crude is often shipped to refineries by shuttle tankers instead of pipelines. Teekay, which is based in the Bahamas, entered the market in March 2001 by buying a Norwegian tanker company, Ugland Nordic Shipping, for $221 million.

Idemitsu, which hopes to cut its debts by more than 8 percent, will close refineries in Kobe and Okinawa, which produce 190,000 barrels a day. Nippon Oil barely earned a profit in the half-year to Sept. 30, while Idemitsu's profits fell 31 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

abstract: Sunken oil tanker Prestige is reported to be leaking up to 37,500 gallons of fuel per day from 15 cracks in its hull; leaking fuel continues to threaten Galician coast, dashing Spanish government hopes that oil will solidify (S)
snippet: Sunken oil tanker Prestige is reported to be leaking up to 37,500 gallons of fuel per day from 15 cracks in its hull; leaking fuel continues to threaten Galician coast, dashing Spanish government hopes that oil will solidify (S)
lead_paragraph: The government said the sunken tanker Prestige was leaking up to 37,500 gallons of fuel oil a day, contradicting official optimism that the 18 million gallon cargo would solidify on the sea bed. A day after Prime Minister José María Aznar acknowledged making mistakes in the handling of the disaster, officials said 15 cracks were leaking oil from the two halves of the tanker's hull, and at least two major slicks were threatening the rich fishing grounds of Galicia, where more than 550 miles of coastline have been polluted. Emma Daly (NYT)

snippet: Review of year's notable ideas and developments notes efforts to stop civil wars in Africa, Asia and Latin America by cutting off funds of guerrillas who finance their armies through illegal export of commodities: timber, diamonds, oil and coca (M...
lead_paragraph: This year brought several peace initiatives based on an important new idea: the quickest way to stop a civil war is to cut off the funds of those doing the fighting. Throughout Africa and in parts of Asia and Latin America, guerrillas finance their armies through the illegal export of commodities: timber, diamonds, oil and coca. Policy makers are now trying to encourage guerrillas to give up their fight by cutting off the money spigot. An embargo, they believe, can put rebels out of business or drive them to the negotiating table.

abstract: Darcy Frey article examines BP's $200 million corporate rebranding and other efforts to remake itself into eco-friendly company, under leadership of CEO Lord John Browne; BP is world's second-largest oil company with gross revenues of $174 billion and 15,500 service stations in US; operates in more than 100 countries and produces almost 3.5 billion barrels of oil and gas annually; environmentalists see new campaign, which included several missteps, as highest form of hypocrisy; Browne is trying to prepare BP for end of fossil-fuel era as he directs company's focus to cleaner fuels, lower emissions and renewable energy resources; whether company can survive is open question; BP has been willing to confront unpleasant truth that business practices and core products are probable causes of global warming and has sought advice on reducing greenhouse-gas emissions and setting up market-based solutions to bring company into compliance with Kyoto Protocols; photos (L)
snippet: Darcy Frey article examines BP's $200 million corporate rebranding and other efforts to remake itself into eco-friendly company, under leadership of CEO Lord John Browne; BP is world's second-largest oil company with gross revenues of $174 billion...
lead_paragraph: Last March, Lord John Browne, the group chief executive of the British oil giant BP, gave a speech at Stanford University. Had you stumbled into the auditorium partway through, you might be forgiven for assuming the man at the podium was not an oil baron, an industrialist, an extractor of fossil fuels from the tender earth but an environmentalist of the high church calling for the abolition of hydrocarbons, the very substance that had made his company and himself so fabulously rich. His subject was global climate change -- in particular, the process by which humans, by burning oil and gas, have been slowly, perhaps irreversibly, warming the earth's atmosphere. And instead of hewing to the line of industry, instead of calling (as President Bush and the head of Exxon Mobil have) for caution and further research, he said, ''I believe the American people expect a company like BP . . . to offer answers and not excuses.'' He also said, ''Climate change is an issue which raises fundamental questions about the relationship between companies and society as a whole, and between one generation and the next.'' He even said, ''Companies composed of highly skilled and trained people can't live in denial of mounting evidence gathered by hundreds of the most reputable scientists in the world.''

headline.main: How Green Is BP?
headline.print_headline: How Green Is BP?

snippet: Spain's Deputy Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy reports largest mass of oil caused by sinking of tanker Prestige is 17 miles off coast of Spain and, due to weather conditions, is moving inland quickly; more than 7,000 fishermen are already unemployed ...
lead_paragraph: A huge oil slick spilled by the tanker Prestige as it sank 11 days ago threatened to hit the northwest coast of Spain, an area already ravaged by earlier spills from the Prestige. ''The really big slick, the main one, is closing in on the coast right now because of weather conditions,'' said Mariano Rajoy, the deputy prime minister, who said it was 17 miles from the coast. More than 7,000 fishermen and shell-fish harvesters are already out of work because fishing has been banned along more than 340 miles of tarnished coastline. The new slick could devastate what remains of Galicia's rich fishing grounds. Emma Daly (NYT)

abstract: Premcor Inc will buy Tennessee oil refinery from Williams Companies for $465 million (S)
snippet: Premcor Inc will buy Tennessee oil refinery from Williams Companies for $465 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Williams Companies, which had its credit rating cut three levels on Friday, agreed to sell a Tennessee oil refinery for $465 million. Williams, the No. 2 natural gas pipeline owner in the United States after El Paso, wants to raise cash to shore up its balance sheet. Premcor Inc. will pay $315 million cash for the plant, which can process 190,000 barrels of oil daily. Williams has agreed to sell about $5 billion in assets this year. The company, which has more than $12 billion in debt, is also seeking buyers for its 70,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Alaska, a spokesman said.

lead_paragraph: Yukos Oil, Russia's second-largest oil producer, plans to increase production by as much as 18 percent next year, expanding output more than twice as fast as the national average rate for the third consecutive year, a spokesman said yesterday. Yukos Oil has championed a push by Russia, the world's biggest oil producer in the mid-1980's, to increase its share of the global market and regain the top spot it lost to Saudi Arabia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Yukos started shipping oil directly to the United States this year to get a foot into the American energy market, the world's biggest.

abstract: Gale winds are blowing oil that leaked from tanker Prestige before ship split in two and sank toward Spain's north shore; debate intensifies over speeding process of phasing out tankers with unlined hulls; photo (M)
snippet: Gale winds are blowing oil that leaked from tanker Prestige before ship split in two and sank toward Spain's north shore; debate intensifies over speeding process of phasing out tankers with unlined hulls; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: VILLAGERS raced to harvest clams and mussels along Spain's north shore ahead of arriving ankle-deep mats of pudding-thick fuel oil, blown by gale winds from Prestige, a sinking tanker. Over six days, as cracks amidships lengthened, more than 2.5 million gallons of oil leaked from the Bahamas-registered Prestige before it finally split in two and sank 100 miles offshore on Tuesday. Debate intensified in Europe over accelerating what is a decade-plus process of phasing out tankers with unlined hulls, like that of the 26-year-old Prestige. The ship -- owned, managed, chartered and registered in four different countries -- had passed inspections earlier in the year. But officials and environmentalists said that single-layer hulls, particularly those over a quarter-century old, lack sufficient strength to carry oil safely. For the moment, there were no signs that the 17-million gallons of oil inside the bow and stern sections, which sank two miles to the sea bed, was headed to the surface. Experts said chilly temperatures at that depth probably gave the oil the consistency of chewing gum. ANDREW C. REVKIN

abstract: Group of oil companies led by Royal Dutch/Shell warns Russian government that it will not move forward with $8.5 billion phase of oil and gas development project in Russia unless country adopts laws to make tax environment more stable (S)
snippet: Group of oil companies led by Royal Dutch/Shell warns Russian government that it will not move forward with $8.5 billion phase of oil and gas development project in Russia unless country adopts laws to make tax environment more stable (S)
lead_paragraph: A group of oil companies led by Royal Dutch/Shell has warned the Russian government that it will not move forward with an $8.5 billion phase of an oil and gas development project in Russia unless the country adopts laws to make the tax environment more stable. Steve McVeigh, chief executive of the group, which is 55 percent owned by Shell, was quoted by Dow Jones Newswires at a London conference as saying that if the laws were not amended, Phase 2 of the project would not proceed. The legislation, which Russian parliamentarians have said would be adopted by the end of this year, has been sought for years by investors, who say Russia's tax system is currently too unstable to make multibillion-dollar investments. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Mara Mahia Op-Ed article says sinking of oil tanker Prestige off Spanish coast is fourth major spill in last thirty years near where she grew up; describes city of La Coruna as one of most beautiful in Spain, explaining that its people have Celtic roots and London-like weather, and culture and economy that still center around fishing (M)
snippet: Mara Mahia Op-Ed article says sinking of oil tanker Prestige off Spanish coast is fourth major spill in last thirty years near where she grew up; describes city of La Coruna as one of most beautiful in Spain, explaining that its people have Celtic...
lead_paragraph: The sinking of the oil tanker, the Prestige, off the coast of Spain this week feels all too familiar to me. I grew up in La Coruña, Spain, a city about 100 miles from where the ship went down. This is the fourth major oil spill in the last 30 years that has taken place near the coastal city that much of my family still calls home.

abstract: Editorial says damaging oil spill off Spanish coast is sobering reminder that world's heavy reliance on oil carries environmental risks that need more urgent attention; questions industry oversight in light of reported problems with 26-year-old tanker Prestige
snippet: Editorial says damaging oil spill off Spanish coast is sobering reminder that world's heavy reliance on oil carries environmental risks that need more urgent attention; questions industry oversight in light of reported problems with 26-year-old ta...
lead_paragraph: The damaging oil spill off the coast of Spain is a sobering reminder that the world's heavy reliance on oil for energy carries environmental risks that need more urgent attention than they have been getting. This was an accident just waiting to happen -- a large shipment of oil carried by an aging, single-hulled tanker that had no business even being in the oil business. If any good is to come of this accident, it must serve as a goad to the industrialized world's governments to speed up their lackadaisical transition to double-hulled ships, a much-touted reform that will not be completed until 2015.

abstract: The crippled tanker Prestige, carrying more than 77,000 tons of fuel oil, split in two and sank off the Spanish coast.
snippet: The crippled tanker Prestige, carrying more than 77,000 tons of fuel oil, split in two and sank off the Spanish coast.
lead_paragraph: MADRID, Nov. 19 — In a sinking foretold by anxious environmentalists and fishermen, the crippled tanker Prestige, carrying more than 77,000 tons of fuel oil, split in two and sank in the Atlantic Ocean 133 miles off the Spanish coast, threatening to cause an environmental catastrophe in the area's rich fishing grounds.

abstract: Lukoil, largest Russian oil producer, agrees to sell its 10 percent ownership in Caspian Sea oil fields off coast of Azerbaijan for $1.2 billion (S)
snippet: Lukoil, largest Russian oil producer, agrees to sell its 10 percent ownership in Caspian Sea oil fields off coast of Azerbaijan for $1.2 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: Russia's largest oil producer, Lukoil, said it had agreed to sell its 10 percent stake in a large set of Caspian Sea oil fields off the coast of Azerbaijan for $1.2 billion. The company said it decided to sell its stake in the Azeri-Chirag-Gunashli fields to streamline its business and sell off assets in which it was not the main operator. Steven Dashevsky, a senior oil analyst at the Moscow-based Aton brokerage firm, said the sale showed Lukoil was finally beginning to make good on pledges to cut costs.

abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro reports $650 million net consolidated third-quarter profit, 45 percent higher than in 2001 period; revenue rose 34 percent, to $5.8 billion; production increased 13 percent and exports rose 59 percent (S)
snippet: Petroleo Brasileiro reports $650 million net consolidated third-quarter profit, 45 percent higher than in 2001 period; revenue rose 34 percent, to $5.8 billion; production increased 13 percent and exports rose 59 percent (S)
lead_paragraph: Brazil's state oil giant, Petróleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, posted a $650 million net consolidated profit in the third quarter, 45 percent higher than in the period last year, the company said. Revenue rose 34 percent, to $5.8 billion, as the company increased production by 13 percent and exports by 59 percent. Despite the income, the company's debt has risen 50 percent since the end of June, to $7.8 billion, because of the weakness of the currency, the real, against the dollar. Tony Smith (NYT)

abstract: Dilapidated tanker causing 20 mile oil slick off coast of Spain is towed out to sea in hopes of preventing further environmental disaster (S)
snippet: Dilapidated tanker causing 20 mile oil slick off coast of Spain is towed out to sea in hopes of preventing further environmental disaster (S)
lead_paragraph: An aging tanker leaking fuel oil that left a 20-mile slick off the coast of northwestern Spain was towed toward international waters last night in the hope of averting an environmental disaster. The high winds and 25-foot waves buffeting the tanker died down at midday, allowing tugs to haul the ship out to sea and enabling technicians to restart an engine. Officials said the ship would be escorted 120 miles offshore and probably turned over to a salvage company to be taken into harbor for repair. Emma Daly (NYT)

abstract: Energy trader Mirant says that bookkeeping errors caused it to overstate profit by $41 million since 1999 and that federal prosecutors continue investigating its accounting and that of rivals (S)
snippet: Energy trader Mirant says that bookkeeping errors caused it to overstate profit by $41 million since 1999 and that federal prosecutors continue investigating its accounting and that of rivals (S)
lead_paragraph: Mirant, an energy trader, said yesterday that bookkeeping errors had caused it to overstate profit by $41 million since 1999, and that federal prosecutors were investigating its accounting. Mirant, whose shares have plunged 88 percent in a year, overstated net income by $51 million from 1999 through 2001 and underreported net income by $10 million during the first six months of this year. Mirant had about $1 billion in net income over the period, it said. The company also disclosed in a government filing that the Justice Department sought copies of documents requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its investigation of energy trading and accounting by Mirant and rivals. Share of Mirant fell 79 cents, or 27 percent, to $2.15.

headline.main: MIRANT SAYS PROFITS WERE OVERSTATED BY $41 MILLION

abstract: Flow of crude oil from Alaska's North Slope resumes after repairs are completed on Trans-Alaska Pipeline; it was shut down Nov 3 when earthquake broke half-dozen energy-absorbing supports (S)
snippet: Flow of crude oil from Alaska's North Slope resumes after repairs are completed on Trans-Alaska Pipeline; it was shut down Nov 3 when earthquake broke half-dozen energy-absorbing supports (S)
lead_paragraph: The flow of crude oil from Alaska's North Slope resumed after repairs were completed on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, which was shut down on Sunday when an earthquake broke a half-dozen energy-absorbing supports, officials said. The pipeline itself -- designed to absorb the force of a magnitude 8.0 quake -- was undamaged by the seven-foot shift in the earth under Sunday's magnitude 7.9 temblor. With a helicopter and spill crews on alert in case of trouble, the flow resumed at midday at half its million-barrel-a-day capacity, but state officials said they expected the pipeline to be back to normal flows in a day or so. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

snippet: Mobil Oil pays $11.2-million fine for polluting two ponds at its Northeast distribution terminal in Staten Island (S)
lead_paragraph: The Mobil Oil Corporation has paid an $11.2 million fine for polluting two ponds at its Northeast distribution terminal in Staten Island, the United States attorney's office said yesterday. About $3 million of the settlement would go toward buying and preserving land on Staten Island. Mobil released oil byproducts from its barges on the site and contaminated the ponds with benzene, Stanley N. Alpert of the attorney's office said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Grant Prideco said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a drill-bit maker, Reed-Hycalog, from Schlumberger for about $345 million in cash and stock to add to its line of oil field tools. Grant Prideco will pay $255 million in cash and about 10 million of its own shares, the chief financial officer, Louis A. Raspino, said. The company will also assume about $5 million in debt from Schlumberger, an oil-services company.

lead_paragraph: Environmentalists in this cloud forest of northern Ecuador still dream of halting construction of a new oil pipeline that the builders said could bring spectacular wealth to this poor Andean country. But with the 300-mile-long, privately financed pipeline now 70 percent complete, and long green tubes replacing the palm and canelo trees, even the most die-hard opponents acknowledge that stopping the construction is next to impossible.

abstract: Seven oil companies will pay nearly $250,000 to contribute to cleanup of contaminated sites in Monmouth County, NJ; companies stored oil waste in lagoons on two SuperFund sites (S)
snippet: Seven oil companies will pay nearly $250,000 to contribute to cleanup of contaminated sites in Monmouth County, NJ; companies stored oil waste in lagoons on two SuperFund sites (S)
lead_paragraph: Seven oil companies will pay nearly $250,000 to contribute to the cleanup of contaminated sites in Monmouth County. The companies had stored oil waste in lagoons on the two Superfund sites. The waste ultimately spread and contaminated 75 acres of land. The companies agreed to the payment as part of a consent decree between federal and state environmental agencies and the owners of the land. Cleanup is expected to be completed by 2005. The companies are Exxon and Mobil, both of Virginia; Atlantic Richfield Company, of California; British Petroleum Products of North America, of Illinois; Shell Oil, of Texas; Chevron Oil, of California; and Sunoco, of Pennsylvania. Stacy Albin (NYT)

abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro SA plans to build 450-mile, $1.1 billion pipeline linking offshore oil wells to onshore refineries (S)
snippet: Petroleo Brasileiro SA plans to build 450-mile, $1.1 billion pipeline linking offshore oil wells to onshore refineries (S)
lead_paragraph: Petróleo Brasileiro S.A., Brazil's state-controlled petroleum producer, plans to build a $1.1 billion pipeline linking offshore oil wells to refineries near São Paulo to handle rising output. The 450-mile oil line network should begin operating in 2005 and will include a pumping platform to send the oil from wells in the Campos Basin to the coast, a spokesman, Celso Mansur, said. The pipeline is a part of Petrobras's $33 billion plan to increase output by another 40 percent, to 2.5 million barrels a day by 2006. Petrobras now relies on ships to take crude to a port near refineries in São Paulo.

lead_paragraph: The former director of Mexico's state oil company, Pemex, was arrested in Houston and faces extradition in a corruption investigation. Rogelio Montemayor, a fugitive since May, faces charges of funneling tens of millions of dollars from Pemex to the Institutional Revolutionary Party during Mexico's 2000 presidential election campaign. The party's candidate, Francisco Labastida, was defeated by President Vicente Fox. Four of Mr. Labastida's campaign aides are under investigation. Tim Weiner (NYT)

abstract: Pure Resources senior managers agree to sell their shares in company after Unocal Corp raises its bid for 35 percent of company it does not already own; revised offers if for $376.9 million (S)
snippet: Pure Resources senior managers agree to sell their shares in company after Unocal Corp raises its bid for 35 percent of company it does not already own; revised offers if for $376.9 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Senior managers at Pure Resources Inc. agreed to sell their shares in the company, an oil and natural gas explorer and producer, after the Unocal Corporation raised its bid for the 35 percent of the company it does not already own. Pure Resources executives accepted a bid of 0.74 Unocal share for each of theirs, the companies said. The revised offer is for $376.9 million, or $21.48 a share, based on Unocal's closing price yesterday. Unocal is seeking full ownership of the company, which it helped create in May 2000 when it combined its West Texas oil and gas unit with Titan Exploration. Unocal, based in El Segundo, Calif., already owns 65 percent of Pure.

lead_paragraph: A French oil tanker was on fire off the southeastern coast of Yemen after an explosion this morning as it headed for an oil terminal in the Gulf of Aden. By late tonight, the cause of the blast aboard the tanker Limburg was still unclear, but the incident immediately raised fears that terrorists had attacked one of the most vulnerable links in the oil-dependent global economy two years after an explosive-filled boat in nearby waters ripped a hole in the United States Navy destroyer Cole.

BP said the annual rise in production would be 4 percent rather than the 5.5 percent forecast in July. Over the last week, BP, Shell and other oil companies have evacuated workers from the gulf because of Tropical Storm Isidore. Alan Cowell (NYT)

abstract: China, which buys its oil imports from Middle East, plans to build $1.5 billion emergency oil reserve in case war or other emergencies disrupt supply; will store about 50 million barrels of crude oil, or 25 days' worth of net imports; China imports about 30 percent of its oil (S)
snippet: China, which buys its oil imports from Middle East, plans to build $1.5 billion emergency oil reserve in case war or other emergencies disrupt supply; will store about 50 million barrels of crude oil, or 25 days' worth of net imports; China import...
lead_paragraph: China, which buys half its oil imports from the Middle East, plans to build a $1.5 billion emergency oil reserve in case war or other emergencies disrupt supply, the head of the International Energy Agency said. China, the second-largest energy user after the United States, would store about 50 million barrels of crude oil, or 25 days' worth of net imports, Robert Priddle, executive director of the agency, said after meeting Chinese officials. China, which is not a member of the agency, imports about 30 percent of its oil.

lead_paragraph: On issues large and small, the Bush administration has spent the better part of two years rolling back Bill Clinton's environmental legacy. It has abandoned the Kyoto accord on global warming, weakened protections for wetlands and eased mining laws. Now it appears to be aiming at even bigger game -- the National Environmental Policy Act, regarded as the Magna Carta of environmental protection and perhaps the most important of all the environmental statutes signed into law by Richard Nixon three decades ago.

abstract: TotalFinaElf, Eni and Repsol YPF, three of Europe's five biggest oil companies, agree to buy oil directly from Iraq after it eliminates surcharge on sales of crude; turnaround may signal end of decline in Iraqi oil sales (M)
snippet: TotalFinaElf, Eni and Repsol YPF, three of Europe's five biggest oil companies, agree to buy oil directly from Iraq after it eliminates surcharge on sales of crude; turnaround may signal end of decline in Iraqi oil sales (M)
lead_paragraph: TotalFinaElf, Eni and Repsol YPF, three of Europe's five biggest oil companies, agreed to buy oil directly from Iraq after it dropped a surcharge on sales. For Total of France, this week's purchase was the first in two years, a spokeswoman said, declining to specify the size of the cargo. Eni of Italy bought a million barrels of Iraqi oil, said Luciana Santaroni, a spokeswoman. Repsol YPF of Spain has agreed to oil exports and is awaiting United Nations clearance. The return of European companies to Iraqi ports may mean the end of a decline in sales from the nation, the Middle East's fifth-largest oil producer. Sales slid this year because of the surcharge and growing wariness about trading with the country.

abstract: Mark Schroeder and Waldo Schroeder, brothers, are sentenced for their role in scheme that allowed hundreds of millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in New York City area, are sentenced (S)
snippet: Mark Schroeder and Waldo Schroeder, brothers, are sentenced for their role in scheme that allowed hundreds of millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in New York City area, are sentenced (S)
lead_paragraph: Two brothers who pleaded guilty to a scheme that allowed hundreds of millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in the New York City area have been sentenced by a federal judge. The brothers, Mark and Waldo Schroeder, were executives with Blending Marketing and Service Inc., a defunct company based in Houston. The brothers admitted being part of a ring that falsified the results of chemical tests indicating that the gasoline passed clean-burning standards required in the Northeast for eight years. The brothers were the last of 10 defendants to be sentenced in the case, officials said. Mark Schroeder, the company's operations manager, was sentenced Tuesday to 11 months in prison, 5 months' house arrest and a $25,000 fine. Waldo Schroeder, the president, was sentenced to six months' house arrest and fined $10,000. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

abstract: Russia and Azerbaijan sign agreement dividing their share of Caspian Sea and its potentially rich gas and oil reserves; agreement bypasses Iran and Turkmenistan, which also border sea and have argued for broad multilateral agreement; map (S)
snippet: Russia and Azerbaijan sign agreement dividing their share of Caspian Sea and its potentially rich gas and oil reserves; agreement bypasses Iran and Turkmenistan, which also border sea and have argued for broad multilateral agreement; map (S)
lead_paragraph: Russia and Azerbaijan signed an agreement dividing up their share of the Caspian Sea, along with its potentially rich gas and oil reserves. The agreement -- signed by Presidents Vladimir V. Putin and Heydar Aliyev in Moscow -- essentially bypassed Iran and Turkmenistan, which also border the sea and have argued for a broader multilateral agreement dividing its resources. Russia signed a similar agreement with Kazakhstan in May. Iran has argued that the Caspian should be divided equally among the five nations but Russia, Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan have argued that the division should be based on the length of shorelines, leaving Iran and Turkmenistan smaller shares. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

abstract: Premcor Inc, oil refining company that went public in April, says it will lay off 130 workers at plants in Ohio and Texas and offices in St Louis to cut costs; move will save about $15 million per year (S)
snippet: Premcor Inc, oil refining company that went public in April, says it will lay off 130 workers at plants in Ohio and Texas and offices in St Louis to cut costs; move will save about $15 million per year (S)
lead_paragraph: Premcor Inc., an oil refining company that went public in April, said yesterday that it would lay off 130 workers at plants in Ohio and Texas and offices in St. Louis to cut costs. About 20 percent of 650 nonunion jobs at refineries in Port Arthur, Tex., and Lima, Ohio, and its St. Louis administrative offices will be eliminated, resulting in a third-quarter charge of about $10 million, the company said. The job cuts will save about $15 million a year. Job cuts at the refineries will be made in October with about half of the annual savings realized in the fourth quarter, Premcor said. The rest will be reflected in the first quarter of 2003. Premcor is based in Old Greenwich, Conn.

abstract: BP cuts its goal for growth in oil and gas production this year because of shutdowns at oil fields in Alaska and British natural gas pipeline; expects growth of 4.5 percent to 5 percent, less than 5.5 percent previously forecast (S)
snippet: BP cuts its goal for growth in oil and gas production this year because of shutdowns at oil fields in Alaska and British natural gas pipeline; expects growth of 4.5 percent to 5 percent, less than 5.5 percent previously forecast (S)
lead_paragraph: BP cut its goal for growth in oil and gas production this year because of shutdowns at oil fields in Alaska and a British natural gas pipeline. BP expects growth this year of 4.5 percent to 5 percent, less than the 5.5 percent previously forecast, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. BP's shares fell 3.5 percent, wiping more than £3 billion ($4.7 billion) off the company's value. Five weeks ago the chief executive, Lord Browne, assured investors that full-year targets would be reached. BP cited setbacks in August associated with an oil field in Britain, a natural gas pipeline from Britain to Continental Europe, and at the Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska.

abstract: Colombian exports rise 3.3 percent in July on surging oil sales abroad; US holds its position as largest single recipient of Colombian goods (S)
snippet: Colombian exports rise 3.3 percent in July on surging oil sales abroad; US holds its position as largest single recipient of Colombian goods (S)
lead_paragraph: Colombian exports rose 3.3 percent in July on surging oil sales abroad, the government's statistics agency said. Total exports increased to $1.04 billion in July from $1.01 billion in the month last year, with the United States holding its position as the largest single recipient of Colombian goods as it bought more than 40 percent of the total. Sales of oil and its derivatives, the country's largest export, surged 18 percent to $272 million in the month. Coal, the second-biggest export, brought in $55.4 million, a drop of 21 percent from the same month last year. Coffee sales abroad fell 7.3 percent to $51.9 million.

The project will increase production of heavy Maya crude from the oil field to 800,000 barrels a day from 263,000 by 2011. Pemex did not say how it would finance the project, which involves drilling 82 new wells and building 17 new platforms.

abstract: Group of small-business owners asks Bush administration not to allow drilling for oil in areas of southern Utah that have become tourist attractions for their scenic beauty; says potential value of oil would be less than $1 billion annually, compared with $4.25 billion that tourists annually spend there (S)
snippet: Group of small-business owners asks Bush administration not to allow drilling for oil in areas of southern Utah that have become tourist attractions for their scenic beauty; says potential value of oil would be less than $1 billion annually, compa...
lead_paragraph: A group of small-business owners asked the Bush administration not to allow drilling for oil in areas of southern Utah that have become tourist attractions for their scenic beauty. In a letter to the White House, the group said drilling would ''forever destroy the pristine landscapes'' that it called ''the bedrock for drawing significant revenue.'' The administration has proposed opening up more of the West to the energy industry, but the group said the potential value of the oil in the areas of Utah in question would be less than $1 billion annually, compared with the $4.25 billion that tourists annually spend there. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

abstract: Neuquen, Argentine city of 250,000 that has prided itself as gateway to Patagonia, is center of increasingly restive movement to secede from economic disaster that is rest of Argentina; deepening economic crisis has resulted in sharp cuts in public service for Patagonians, even as region's bounty of natural resources continues generating income for central government; longstanding resentment of Government has intensified; political autonomy, regional integration and even secession are being openly discussed as solutions; independent Patagonia would be sparsely populated but prosperous nation; fewer that 5 percent of Argentina's 37 million people live there, but region accounts for nearly half of country's territory, much of its fresh water supply and hydroelectric power and 80 percent of its oil and gas; region regards itself as neglected stepchild of rest of country; was administered as federal territory, with residents unable to elect their own governors and congressional legislators until 1950's; photos; map (M)

lead_paragraph: On a recent tour of India, I was visiting with an Indian Muslim community leader, Syed Shahabuddin, and the conversation drifted to the question of why the Muslim world seems so angry with the West. ''Whenever I am in America,'' he said, ''people ask me, 'Why do they hate us?' They don't hate you. If they hated you, would they send their kids to be educated by you? Would they look up to you as a model? They hate that you are monopolizing all the nonrenewable resources [oil]. And because you want to do that, you need to keep in power all your collaborators. As a consequence, you support feudal elements who are trying to stave off the march of democracy.''

abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp acquires 25 percent stake in pipeline system that will carry oil from field in Gulf of Mexico; price undisclosed; buys fourth of both Proteus Pipeline Co and Endymion Pipeline Co, which plan to build pipeline system that will be operated by BP (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil Corp acquires 25 percent stake in pipeline system that will carry oil from field in Gulf of Mexico; price undisclosed; buys fourth of both Proteus Pipeline Co and Endymion Pipeline Co, which plan to build pipeline system that will be o...
lead_paragraph: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it bought a 25 percent stake in a pipeline system that would carry oil from a field in the Gulf of Mexico. The price was not disclosed. Exxon, which is based in Irving, Tex., bought a fourth of both the Proteus Pipeline Company and the Endymion Pipeline Company. Those companies plan to build a 420,000-barrel-a-day pipeline system to carry oil from the Thunder Horse field 150 miles offshore, southeast of New Orleans, Exxon said. The pipeline will be operated by BP, which is based in London.

lead_paragraph: A Russian oil concern, Yukos Oil, had a victory in an American court battle against Dardana, an investment company that says Yukos owes it $17 million. A federal judge on Wednesday refused to confirm Dardanas's claim that Yukos shirked payment for oil services in the mid-1990's in Russia and transferred the case to state court. Yukos, Russia's No. 2 oil producer, shipped a tanker of oil to Texas on July 3, but payment for the oil was frozen by the court. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell agrees to pay $28 million to help clean up groundwater near Lake Tahoe that was contaminated by gasoline additive (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell agrees to pay $28 million to help clean up groundwater near Lake Tahoe that was contaminated by gasoline additive (S)
lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch/Shell agreed yesterday to pay $28 million to help clean up groundwater near Lake Tahoe that was contaminated by a gasoline additive, a lawyer for a utility district said. The settlement in San Francisco ends a 10-month trial in which a jury said oil companies maliciously failed to warn a local utility district of the dangers of methyl tertiary-butyl ether. The additive leaked from underground gasoline tanks near the lake on the California-Nevada border and the utility sued. A spokesman said that other cases would be reviewed individually.

abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column reports he has lost track of whether Pentagon plans to invade Iraq from three or four sides and whether US will be using Jordan, Kuwait or Diego Garcia as launching pad, but has seen little planning for impact attack would have on oil market; says raising oil question is not argument against taking down Saddam Hussein, but quotes foreign relations expert Philip K Verleger's warning that attack would be 'extraordinarily high-risk economic adventure' that could destabilize several countries or, if it goes wrong, cause prolonged disruption of world oil supplies (M)
snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column reports he has lost track of whether Pentagon plans to invade Iraq from three or four sides and whether US will be using Jordan, Kuwait or Diego Garcia as launching pad, but has seen little planning for impact attack...
lead_paragraph: Reading the papers lately, I've lost track of whether the Pentagon plans to invade Iraq from three sides or four, and whether we will be using Jordan, Kuwait or Diego Garcia as our main launching pad. But one thing I haven't seen much planning for is the impact an attack on Iraq would have on the world's oil market. Depending on how the war went, that impact could be very bad and lead to a sharp spike in oil prices, like $60-a-barrel oil. But -- wait a minute -- it could also be very good, and lead to $6-a-barrel oil that would weaken OPEC and, maybe, also weaken the Arab autocrats who depend on high oil prices to finance their illegitimate regimes and buy off opponents.

abstract: Senate Foreign Relations Committee holds first public hearings on Bush administration's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein from Iraqi presidency; array of experts warn that invasion of Iraq would carry significant risks ranging from more terrorist attacks against American targets to higher oil prices; some experts call for swift, large-scale attack to depose Hussein before his biological and nuclear weapons capabilities mature; others argue for tighter embargo and more aggressive weapons inspections to contain him; all agree that if Pres Bush does use military force to remove Hussein, Pentagon should not underestimate ability of Iraqi military to fight or overestimate ability of Iraqi opposition forces to carry on fight alone; say American forces would prevail in invasion, but that administration should plan on keeping forces in Iraq for many years to help rebuild it; there is growing concern in Congress that administration is moving rapidly, and without public debate, toward full-scale military assault on Iraq, and there is emerging debate over whether Bush would need Congressional approval for such an invasion (M)
snippet: Senate Foreign Relations Committee holds first public hearings on Bush administration's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein from Iraqi presidency; array of experts warn that invasion of Iraq would carry significant risks ranging from more terrorist att...
lead_paragraph: In the first public hearings on the administration's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein from the Iraqi presidency, an array of experts warned a Senate committee today that an invasion of Iraq would carry significant risks ranging from more terrorist attacks against American targets to higher oil prices.

abstract: Pennzoil-Quaker State earned $28.7 million in second quarter compared with loss of $5.3 million year earlier; revenue was $590 million in contrast to $601 million year ago (S)
snippet: Pennzoil-Quaker State earned $28.7 million in second quarter compared with loss of $5.3 million year earlier; revenue was $590 million in contrast to $601 million year ago (S)
lead_paragraph: Pennzoil-Quaker State said today that it swung to a profit for its second quarter. The company earned $28.7 million, or 34 cents a diluted share, on revenue of $590 million. This was in contrast to a loss of $5.3 million, or 7 cents a share, on revenue of $601 million in the quarter a year ago. In March, Pennzoil-Quaker State agreed to be bought by Shell Oil, the United States affiliate of Royal Dutch/Shell, for $1.8 billion. A shareholder vote is set for Aug. 1.

snippet: World Business Briefing: South Korea: InvestigS
lead_paragraph: S-Oil, Korea's third largest oil company, is the target of an investigation in which police have requested arrest warrants for five senior executives and said they were investigating five others. The police said the executives engaged in manipulation of stock prices and unfairly earned about $70 million. The company reported a net profit last year of more than $22 million, police said, when it actually lost about $6.5 million. The company in which Aramco, the Saudi company, holds a 35 percent stake, expressed confidence that ''a thorough investigation by authorities will find us innocent.''

abstract: Varco International Inc acquires oil-field-services arm of ICO Inc for $136.7 million in cash and assumed debt (S)
snippet: Varco International Inc acquires oil-field-services arm of ICO Inc for $136.7 million in cash and assumed debt (S)
lead_paragraph: Varco International Inc., the maker of oil-drilling equipment that operates in 49 nations, agreed yesterday to buy the oil-field-services arm of ICO Inc. for $136.7 million in cash and assumed debt. It was the second time Varco has agreed to buy the business. ICO's board rejected a $165 million offer recently, saying conditions would have reduced pretax profitability of the sale and produced a substantial tax burden and other liabilities. Since then, ICO shares have fallen 17 percent. Varco is adding ICO's well pipe inspection, coating and reconditioning services in North America, Asia and Europe to its line of oil field services. Both companies are based in Houston. Varco shares rose 38 cents, to $17.16, and ICO shares rose 24 cents, to $1.48.

lead_paragraph: In his article (Nov. 10), Noam Scheiber writes that ''the biggest obstacle to freeing ourselves from Middle Eastern oil has nothing to do with politics.'' On the contrary, I believe it has everything to do with politics. There has been little political will even to modestly improve gas mileage for vehicles. And there has been no political will to implement energy-conservation measures. There is no political will at all to assist in implementing solar power on a large scale, despite the fact that the technology is there. Wind power has grown significantly despite little government support. With government support, there is tremendous potential and opportunity to wean ourselves off Middle Eastern oil.

abstract: Darcy Frey article on pristine wilderness landscapes in Rocky Mountain West threatened by Pres Bush's and Vice Pres Cheney's energy team's proposals for new oil and gas drilling sites; notes only regulatory changes by Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management would be needed for industry to gain greater foothold across much of West; photos (M)
snippet: Darcy Frey article on pristine wilderness landscapes in Rocky Mountain West threatened by Pres Bush's and Vice Pres Cheney's energy team's proposals for new oil and gas drilling sites; notes only regulatory changes by Forest Service and Bureau of ...
lead_paragraph: Landscapes, no less than people, are transformed by the eyes that behold them. When an environmentalist travels the Jack Morrow Hills, in Wyoming's Red Desert, he sees a near-perfect ecosystem of soaring buttes, badlands and shifting sand dunes, while desert elk and pronghorn antelope hoof across the sands, pausing to drink from tiny ponds formed when the winter snows melt between the dunes. At 600,000 acres, the Jack Morrow Hills are part of this country's largest untouched high-elevation desert, indeed one of the largest roadless areas of any kind in the U.S. -- what Mac Blewer of the Wyoming Outdoor Council likes to call ''the wild heart of the West.'' When an energy developer treads that same path, however, he often sees with a kind of seismic vision, sensing beneath those same geologic sands a portion of the approximately 137 trillion cubic feet of natural gas that is believed to lie within the Rocky Mountain region.

headline.main: Endangered Landscape

abstract: Argentine government agrees to rescind restrictions recently imposed on petroleum exports out of concerns that oil producers will try to circumvent informal price controls (S)
snippet: Argentine government agrees to rescind restrictions recently imposed on petroleum exports out of concerns that oil producers will try to circumvent informal price controls (S)
lead_paragraph: The Argentine government has agreed to rescind restrictions recently imposed on petroleum exports out of concerns that oil producers would try to circumvent informal price controls. With the value of the Argentine currency having fallen more than 70 percent this year, exporting has become far more attractive than supplying the local market, but had been limited to 36 percent of total production. That ceiling was lifted, however, in return for a pledge by Repsol YPF of Spain, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and other producers to assure an adequate fuel supply at current prices throughout the coming winter in the Southern Hemisphere. Larry Rohter (NYT)

snippet: Yukos, Russia's No. 2 oil producer, acquires of 26.85 percent stake in Mazeikiu oil refinery in Lithuania from Williams International and Lithuanian government (S)
lead_paragraph: In another move by a Russian oil company to buy oil assets in Eastern Europe, Yukos, Russia's No. 2 oil producer, completed the purchase of a 26.85 percent stake in the Mazeikiu oil refinery in Lithuania. The agreement was concluded with the refinery's other owners, Williams International of the United States, and the Lithuanian government. Yukos will pay $75 million, lend the refinery a further $75 million and supply it with crude for the next decade. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 7 about an explosion on the French supertanker Limburg off Yemen confused two ways of measuring the ship's size. The Limburg weighs 341,097 tons fully loaded; 298,997 tons is its deadweight tonnage, or the total possible weight of its cargo, fuel, stores and everything else removable from the ship.

abstract: BP PLC and partners including Eni, Statoil and Unocal agree to build $2.9 billion pipeline across Turkey to move Caspian Sea oil to world markets (S)
snippet: BP PLC and partners including Eni, Statoil and Unocal agree to build $2.9 billion pipeline across Turkey to move Caspian Sea oil to world markets (S)
lead_paragraph: Europe's biggest oil company, BP P.L.C., and its partners agreed to build a $2.9 billion pipeline across Turkey to move Caspian Sea oil to world markets, ending more than eight years of debate. The partners, which include Eni of Italy, Statoil of Norway and Unocal of the United States, have completed all the agreements to start construction and will make a final decision later this month, the project director, Philip Allison, said at a conference in Baku, Azerbaijan. The 1,090-mile line will link fields containing as many as 40 billion barrels of oil with the Mediterranean Sea port of Ceyhan.

lead_paragraph: Parker Drilling, an oil and gas drilling contractor based in Houston, offered 162 million Australian dollars ($92.5 million) for the Australian Oil and Gas Corporation of Sydney, topping bids by two Canadian rivals. Parker offered 2.50 Australian dollars a share and 1.30 Australian dollars for each listed option in Australian Oil, 8.7 percent more than the closing price yesterday. lead_paragraph: A Russian company, Amur Shipbuilding, was awarded a $140 million contract by Exxon Mobil to refurbish an oil drilling rig that Exxon Mobil will use to develop the rich oil fields off Sakhalin, an island off the Pacific coast of Russia. abstract: Construction resumes on 650-mile Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline after workers in Cameroon end two-week strike over pay and working conditions (S)
snippet: Construction resumes on 650-mile Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline after workers in Cameroon end two-week strike over pay and working conditions (S)
lead_paragraph: Construction resumed on the Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline after workers in Cameroon ended a two-week strike over pay and working conditions. The 650-mile pipeline, which will carry crude oil from Chad to Cameroon's Atlantic coast, is scheduled to be completed in less than two years. The project, backed by the World Bank, is expected to yield $2 billion over 25 years to Chad, a landlocked nation with few other resources. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

snippet: Newfield Exploration, oil and gas explorer that agreed on May 29 to buy rival EEX Corp, plans to sell $70 million in offshore assets after acquisition is completed; Newfield will pay $640 million in stock and assumed debt for EEX (S)
lead_paragraph: Newfield Exploration, an oil and gas explorer that agreed on Wednesday to buy a rival, the EEX Corporation, plans to sell $70 million in offshore assets after the acquisition is completed, its chief executive said. Newfield will pay $640 million in stock and assumed debt for EEX, giving it access to deep-water fields in the Gulf of Mexico. The assets to be sold, which include a floating oil and natural gas production platform and 53 miles of underwater pipelines, were valued by EEX last year at $70 million, Newfield's chief executive, David A. Trice, said. Newfield will pay 0.05703 share for each EEX share, or a total of 7.1 million shares, and assume $360 million in debt.

abstract: Conoco Inc says its Conoco Canada Resources unit has agreed to buy rest of oil and natural gas producer Gulf Indonesia Resources Ltd that it does not already own for $329 million (S)
snippet: Conoco Inc says its Conoco Canada Resources unit has agreed to buy rest of oil and natural gas producer Gulf Indonesia Resources Ltd that it does not already own for $329 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that its Conoco Canada Resources unit agreed to buy the rest of the oil and natural gas producer Gulf Indonesia Resources Ltd. that it did not already own for $329 million. Conoco will pay $13.25 a share in cash for the 28 percent stake, a Conoco spokesman, Peter Hunt, said. The price is 23 percent more than Gulf Indonesia's closing price on Friday. Conoco last year bought Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., which owned 72 percent of Gulf Indonesia, for $6.3 billion in cash and assumed debt to increase its oil and natural gas reserves. The purchase was the largest ever of a Canadian oil company.

abstract: Delta Petroleum Corp acquires all of Castle Energy Corp's oil and gas properties in US for about $57.3 million in stock and cash to double its daily production of oil (S)
snippet: Delta Petroleum Corp acquires all of Castle Energy Corp's oil and gas properties in US for about $57.3 million in stock and cash to double its daily production of oil (S)
lead_paragraph: The Delta Petroleum Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company, has agreed to buy all of the Castle Energy Corporation's oil and gas properties in the United States for about $57.3 million in stock and cash to double its daily production of oil. Delta said it would pay $20 million in cash and about 9.57 million shares for the assets of Castle. The value was based on Delta's closing price on Monday of $3.90 a share. Shares of Castle, which is based in Radnor, Pa., rose $1.33, or 25 percent, to $6.53. Delta will get 525 oil and gas wells in 14 states, the chief executive, Roger Parker, said. Delta is based in Denver.

abstract: National Academy of Sciences reports that most oil pollution in North American coastal waters comes not from leaking tankers or oil rigs, but rather from countless oil-streaked streets, sputtering lawn mowers and other dispersed sources on land and that pollution from these sources will be hard to prevent; says thousands of tiny releases, carried by streams and storm drains to sea, equal Exxon Valdez spill -- 10.9 million gallons of petroleum -- every eight months; says spills from tankers, barges and other oil transport vessels totaled less than quarter-million gallons in 1999, down from more than six million in 1990; says more than half oil runoff in North America occurs along East Coast between Maine and Virginia; says oil carried in runoff is particularly damaging because it typically ends up discharged by rivers and streams into bays and estuaries that are most sensitive ecological areas along coast; says another significant source of pollution are two-cycle engines still used in many outboard boats and personal watercraft (M)
snippet: National Academy of Sciences reports that most oil pollution in North American coastal waters comes not from leaking tankers or oil rigs, but rather from countless oil-streaked streets, sputtering lawn mowers and other dispersed sources on land an...
lead_paragraph: Most oil pollution in North American coastal waters comes not from leaking tankers or oil rigs, but rather from countless oil-streaked streets, sputtering lawn mowers and other dispersed sources on land, and so will be hard to prevent, a panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences says in a new report.

abstract: Editorial welcomes Pres Bush's moves to limit offshore drilling for oil and natural gas along Florida's Gulf Coast and proposal to buy privately held oil, gas and other mineral rights under three nature preserves adjacent to Everglades National Park; says Bush's sensitivity to Florida, where is brother is governor, contrasts with carelessness that has marked his quest for more oil and gas in some other parts of country
snippet: Editorial welcomes Pres Bush's moves to limit offshore drilling for oil and natural gas along Florida's Gulf Coast and proposal to buy privately held oil, gas and other mineral rights under three nature preserves adjacent to Everglades National Pa...
lead_paragraph: For the second time in a year, President Bush has moved to limit offshore drilling for oil and natural gas along Florida's Gulf Coast. He also proposed to buy the privately held oil, gas and other mineral rights under three nature preserves adjacent to Everglades National Park. If approved by Congress, his proposals will protect the beaches that provide much of Florida's tourist income, and will greatly assist the fragile South Florida ecosystem, which has suffered from development and years of official neglect. It is hardly coincidental that they will also help his brother Jeb's re-election prospects in the Florida governor's race this fall.

snippet: Shareholders of Phillips Petroleum Co reject stockholder proposal to link executives' pay to increases in company's market-capitalization ranking, compared with its rivals it is now world's 10th-largest biggest oil company (S)
lead_paragraph: The shareholders of the Phillips Petroleum Company have rejected a stockholder proposal to link executives' pay to increases in the company's market-capitalization ranking, compared with its rivals. It is now the world's 10th-biggest oil company, according to its market value. The company, based in Bartlesville, Okla., expects to merge with a rival, Conoco, to create the seventh-biggest company, according to market value, and the nation's third-largest oil company, based on revenue. Shares of Phillips fell $1.37, to $59.60.

lead_paragraph: Key Energy Services Inc., the oil well-service company, agreed to buy a closely held rival, Q Services Inc. of Houston, for $185 million in stock to expand in the Gulf Coast. Key Energy will also assume $80 million in debt. Key Energy, based in Houston, expects to save $10 million a year with the transaction. It will raise the number of its oilfield-service vehicles by a quarter to 2,050.

snippet: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission raids offices of Caltex Australia, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Exxon Mobil Corp to search for evidence of price collusion at gasoline stations across Australia; motorists' organizations complained abo...
lead_paragraph: Australia's antitrust regulator raided offices of Caltex Australia, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Mobil Corporation to search for evidence of price collusion at gasoline stations. About 90 officers raided 11 sites in Melbourne, Sydney and Newcastle on Tuesday, ''looking for documents and computer hard drives,'' said Lin Enright, a spokeswoman for the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Motorists' organizations had complained about gasoline price increases around Easter. Allan Fels, at left, the commission's chairman, said the oil companies might face fines of as much as 10 million Australian dollars, ($5.4 million) per violation.

abstract: Joseph J Hazelwood, former captain of Exxon Valdez responsible for country's worst oil spill, finishes paying his debt to State of Alaska with $50,000 check; restitution was part of sentence issued in 1990; photo (S)
snippet: Joseph J Hazelwood, former captain of Exxon Valdez responsible for country's worst oil spill, finishes paying his debt to State of Alaska with $50,000 check; restitution was part of sentence issued in 1990; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The ship captain responsible for the country's worst oil spill finished paying his debt to the State of Alaska with a $50,000 check. The restitution was part of a sentence issued in 1990 after a jury convicted the captain of the Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood, for the negligent discharge of oil after the tanker ran aground in 1989. The spill spewed 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound and marred 1,500 miles of coastline. The sentence called for probation, the restitution and 1,000 hours of community service, which he completed last summer. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The Indian conglomerate Reliance Group said two of its biggest companies, Reliance Industries, India's largest petrochemical company, and Reliance Petroleum, India's largest private oil refining company, would merge. The merger was announced Sunday by Anil Ambani, whose family will own more than a third of the new company. Mr. Ambani said that the combined company would be better positioned to make acquisitions and that the company was expected to be a leading bidder for two state-owned oil refining and retailing companies. abstract: Editorial, commenting on Bush administration's submission of pessimistic report on global warming to UN, says Bush still has no serious strategies for climate change and has essentially withdrawn from field (M)
snippet: Editorial, commenting on Bush administration's submission of pessimistic report on global warming to UN, says Bush still has no serious strategies for climate change and has essentially withdrawn from field (M)
lead_paragraph: As it is required to do under international treaty, the Bush administration has sent to the United Nations a report on global warming that is much more pessimistic than its earlier calculations about the environmental damage that unchecked warming could cause. A White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said the report is reason ''to move forward on the president's strategies for addressing the challenge of climate change.'' There is only one thing wrong with this picture. President Bush has no serious strategies for climate change.

abstract: Conoco and Phillips
snippet: Conoco and Phillips
lead_paragraph: Conoco and the Phillips Petroleum Company will lay off an undisclosed number of workers in three cities after they merge later this year to form the nation's third-largest oil company. Jobs will be trimmed in Houston, the combined company's headquarters; in Tempe, Ariz.; and in Ponca City, Okla., the companies said. Most of the cuts will be made by the end of 2003. Conoco and Phillips expect to save $750 million a year from the merger, which is expected to close as early as the third quarter.

abstract: Workers and managers at Venezuela's state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, begin one-day strike, challenging Pres Hugo Chavez to follow through with his threat to militarize company; workers are protesting last month's appointment to board of five employees strikers say were not qualified and were selected for their political loyalty to Chavez; strike has not affected oil production; photo (S)
snippet: Workers and managers at Venezuela's state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, begin one-day strike, challenging Pres Hugo Chavez to follow through with his threat to militarize company; workers are protesting last month's appointment to board of ...
lead_paragraph: Administrators, technicians and managers at Venezuela's state oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela, began a one-day strike, challenging the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez, left, to follow through with his threat to militarize the company. The workers are protesting last month's appointment to the board of five employees the strikers said were not qualified and were selected for their political loyalty to Mr. Chávez. Since then, workers have staged almost daily protests, becoming the focal point for forces opposed to Mr. Chávez. The strike has not affected oil production, said Ruben Silva, a work coordinator for the oil company.

abstract: Nigeria's Supreme Court rules off
snippet: Nigeria's Supreme Court rules off
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled that offshore resources, including potential crude oil and gas deposits, are under the control of the federal government, not state authorities. Six southern states, which produce almost all of Nigeria's oil, had tried to exert control over the ocean off the Niger Delta, where most untapped oil deposits are believed to lie. The federal government has long claimed all the revenues from the crude oil in the region, which received little in return. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

snippet: Russian government next week will decide whether to extend cuts in oil exports as OPEC has requested; Russia's production has been rising as its oil industry is upgraded, creating tension with OPEC (S)
lead_paragraph: The Russian government, in a meeting next week, will decide whether to extend cuts in oil exports as OPEC has requested. The prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, will meet with the chief executives of oil companies to decide whether to extend cuts of 150,000 barrels a day into the second quarter of this year, according to the Russian deputy prime minister, Viktor Khristenko, who was quoted by the Interfax news agency. Russia's production has been rising as its oil industry is upgraded, creating tension with OPEC. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group reported a 42 percent drop in first-quarter profit, amid a slump in energy prices. Net income fell to $2.26 billion, compared with $3.89 billion in the period a year earlier. Rivals like BP and Exxon Mobil have recently reported steep slides in first-quarter profit, reflecting the slowing economy's weakened demand for oil and natural gas. A promise to OPEC to hold down shipments expires on March 31, and there was little sign that it would be extended. The energy minister, Igor Yusufov, told the Russian news agency Interfax that the country should step up exports of refined products to compensate oil companies for the limits on exports of crude. lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch/Shell, the biggest oil company in Europe, said fourth-quarter profit excluding one-time items slumped almost 50 percent as economies slowed after the Sept. 11 terror attacks and oil and gas prices fell. The slide in quarterly net profit to $1.91 billion from $3.58 billion a year ago was steeper than analysts had forecast. Royal Dutch/Shell said lower crude oil prices were responsible for the reduced profit.

lead_paragraph: Russia may scrap reductions in crude oil exports in the second quarter if American and European economies show signs of growth, Mikhail Kasyanov, the Russian prime minister, said after meeting with President Bush in Washington, according to Russia's Itar-Tass news agency. The comment followed a similar statement over the weekend, when Mr. Kasyanov, at the World Economic Forum in New York, said the country's energy strategy is to increase oil production. Russia is flexing its muscles as the world's No. 2 oil producer and its stance has created tension with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which has been pushing for cuts in output to help support prices. abstract: BP says first-quarter profit margins for refining oil and selling fuel fell to their lowest points in decade as reuslt of high levels of supply and lower demand; BP's margins from refining oil were down 30 percent, compared with fourth quarter of 2001; margins from selling fuel declined 45 percent over same period; says it is on target to increase production for year by 5.5 percent; graph (S)
snippet: BP says first-quarter profit margins for refining oil and selling fuel fell to their lowest points in decade as reuslt of high levels of supply and lower demand; BP's margins from refining oil were down 30 percent, compared with fourth quarter of ...
lead_paragraph: BP, the third-largest publicly traded oil company, said that first-quarter profit margins for refining oil and selling fuel fell to their lowest point in a decade as a result of high levels of supply and lower demand. A warm winter and the slowdown in air travel after the Sept. 11 terror attacks helped push BP's margins from refining oil down 30 percent, compared with the fourth quarter of 2001. Margins from selling fuel declined 45 percent over the same period, the company said. BP said it was on target to increase production for the year by 5.5 percent, although most of that growth would come in the second half of the year.

abstract: Helmerich & Payne, US-based drilling contractor, will spin off subsidiary that produces oil and natural gas; new company called Cimarex Energy Co will acquire Key Production Co of Denver in $220 million transaction (S)
snippet: Helmerich & Payne, US-based drilling contractor, will spin off subsidiary that produces oil and natural gas; new company called Cimarex Energy Co will acquire Key Production Co of Denver in $220 million transaction (S)
lead_paragraph: Helmerich & Payne, a United States-based drilling contractor, will spin off a subsidiary that produces oil and natural gas. The new company will acquire the Key Production Company of Denver in a $220 million transaction. Helmerich shareholders will receive 0.53 share of a new company called the Cimarex Energy Company for each Helmerich share, while Key investors will get one Cimarex share for each Key share, the companies said. Cimarex will be owned 65 percent by Helmerich shareholders and 35 percent by Key investors. Helmerich, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., sought the spinoff to separate exploration and production from its drilling business.

abstract: BP reports 69 percent decline in first-quarter profit; earned $924 million compared with $3 billion year earlier; chief executive Lord John Browne comments (S)
snippet: BP reports 69 percent decline in first-quarter profit; earned $924 million compared with $3 billion year earlier; chief executive Lord John Browne comments (S)
lead_paragraph: BP reported a 69 percent decline in first-quarter profit yesterday, stung by lower energy prices and slowing demand. BP earned $924 million, or 7 cents a share, excluding one-time charges, in the quarter, compared with $3 billion, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Output rose 0.8 percent in the first quarter, far less than the 5.5 percent target that BP had set for all of 2002. The slow start is causing some analysts to question whether BP can meet its goal, which is slightly higher than that set by its rivals. Lord Browne, BP's chief executive, said the company remained confident of meeting its target and expected production to increase significantly in the second half of the year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Conoco and Phillips Petroleum said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had asked for more information about their $17 billion merger. The request is routine, a Phillips spokesman said. Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., received a second request from the trade commission when buying a refiner, the Tosco Corporation, in September for $8.37 billion. The merger is still expected to close in the second half, Phillips and Conoco said.

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group will proceed with its planned 3.5 billion pound ($5 billion) acquisition of Enterprise Oil despite new 10 percent tax levied against oil and gas profits from North Sea region; tax is part of British budget prepared by Chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group will proceed with its planned 3.5 billion pound ($5 billion) acquisition of Enterprise Oil despite new 10 percent tax levied against oil and gas profits from North Sea region; tax is part of British budget prepared by Chanc...
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it would proceed with its planned £3.5 billion ($5 billion) acquisition of Enterprise Oil despite a new 10 percent tax levied against oil and gas profits from the North Sea region. The tax was part of the British budget prepared by Gordon Brown, chancellor of the exchequer, and delivered to Parliament on Wednesday. Analysts said the tax could eliminate as much as £35 million in operating profits at Enterprise Oil, which has half its production in the North Sea. In a statement released yesterday, Royal Dutch/Shell said it had bought 43.5 million shares, or 9 percent of the issued share capital, of Enterprise Oil at £7.25 a share.

abstract: BJ Services Co wins $98.1 million judgment for patent infringement against Halliburton Co, rival oil field services company, in case involving hydraulic fracturing method; Halliburton to appeal (S)
snippet: BJ Services Co wins $98.1 million judgment for patent infringement against Halliburton Co, rival oil field services company, in case involving hydraulic fracturing method; Halliburton to appeal (S)
lead_paragraph: The BJ Services Company won a $98.1 million judgment for patent infringement against the Halliburton Company, a rival in the oil field services industry, a law firm representing BJ Services said. Halliburton said it would appeal. The case concerned a method of hydraulic fracturing, which pumps liquid into the ground at high pressure to break open an underground formation so that more oil can be recovered, according to the law firm, Fulbright & Jaworski of Houston. BJ Services, which patented a method in 2000, accused Halliburton of infringing on its patent for two years. The judgment, handed down in United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, is for damages including lost income, the law firm said.

abstract: Michigan Senate passes bill to ban new slant drilling from Michigan shores for oil and gas under Great Lakes (S)
snippet: Michigan Senate passes bill to ban new slant drilling from Michigan shores for oil and gas under Great Lakes (S)
lead_paragraph: The State Senate passed a bill to ban new drilling from Michigan shores for oil and gas under the Great Lakes. The bill, which passed 28 to 5, would abolish slant drilling from onshore sites. Seven existing wells would not be affected. The House, which passed a similar bill, is expected to review the Senate's changes and send the bill to Gov. John Engler. Mr. Engler, who has opposed the bill, said he would not veto it. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Jean Chrétien led a delegation of political leaders from Canada's provinces and 300 business figures to Russia to try to increase trade and Canadian investments in Russian oil fields. Canadian officials said Mr. Chrétien would also like to secure more Russian help in international anti-terrorism efforts and support for his views on increasing world assistance to Africa. lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia will suffer its worst recession this year since 1985 because of a decline in oil production and prices, stalling efforts to cut unemployment, the Saudi American Bank reported. The gross domestic product of the country, the world's largest oil exporter, is expected to contract 2 percent, compared with growth of 1.5 percent in 2001, the bank's chief economist, Brad Bourland, said. The economy contracted 4 percent in 1985.

abstract: BLS reports that steep drop in energy prices helped reduce inflation rate in New York City metropolitan area to 1.7 percent last year, from 3.1 percent in 2000 (S)
snippet: BLS reports that steep drop in energy prices helped reduce inflation rate in New York City metropolitan area to 1.7 percent last year, from 3.1 percent in 2000 (S)
lead_paragraph: A steep drop in energy prices helped reduce the regional inflation rate to 1.7 percent last year, from 3.1 percent in 2000, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday. The rate measures inflation in New York City and its northern suburbs, Long Island, and parts of New Jersey and Connecticut. Gasoline prices have dropped by about a third since peaking in June, the bureau reported. But owner-occupied housing costs rose by 6.6 percent, far more than the 2.4 percent increase in 2000. Rental costs rose only slightly, to 4.1 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

abstract: New drilling for oil and natural gas off coast of central California would be banned under bill in Congress intended to settle dispute between state and Bush administration, which wants to open 40 offshore tracts; deal, proposed by Sen Barbara Boxer, would offer companies incentives to bid instead on tracts in Gulf of Mexico already scheduled for drilling (S)
snippet: New drilling for oil and natural gas off coast of central California would be banned under bill in Congress intended to settle dispute between state and Bush administration, which wants to open 40 offshore tracts; deal, proposed by Sen Barbara Box...
lead_paragraph: New drilling for oil and natural gas off the coast of central California would be banned under a bill in Congress intended to settle a dispute between California and the Bush administration, which wants to open 40 offshore tracts. The deal, proposed by Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, would offer companies with leases on the tracts incentives worth up to $2.8 billion to bid on tracts in the Gulf of Mexico already scheduled for drilling. The California tracts, most off Santa Barbara, would become an ecological preserve. Nick Madigan (NYT)
